awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Use of Results from the Undrain Triaxial Tests to Model Elasto-plastic Behavior for Unsaturated soils: A Feasibility Study
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-Concept Grants for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award provides funding for exploring the feasibility of using undrained tests to characterize unsaturated soils for the purpose of constitutive modeling. This exploratory research will mainly evaluate the influences of stress localizations and subsequent internal drainage on suction distributions of soil specimens during UTT tests and develop effective methods to eliminate such effects. The objectives of the research will be achieved through collecting and analyzing data from existing literature, equipment development, experimental testing, and constitutive modeling. 

This exploratory research is a preliminary study of PI's effort on developing simple and reliable methods to characterize and model fully-coupled elasto-plastic behavior for unsaturated soils.  If successful, it will reduce the testing time required to characterize behavior for unsaturated soils by three orders of magnitude with more reliable measurement, more representative soil behavior, and better understanding of constitutive behavior of unsaturated soil. The test results provide solid experimental basis for resolving arguments regarding some fundamental questions in the field of unsaturated soil mechanics. This proposed research will open up new and exciting doors for fast, practical and more comprehensive and reliable soil behavior characterization. It has the potential to transform the ways of material testing and characterization for coupled problems beyond geotechnical engineering.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Project
Outcomes Report



Project Title: EAGER: Use of Results from the
Undrained Triaxial Tests to Model Elasto-plastic Behavior for Unsaturated
soils: A Feasibility Study



PI: Xiong Zhang



Awardee: University of Alaska Fairbanks Campus



Award Number: 1054532



Award Expires: 12/31/2012



Program Officer Name: Richard J. Fragaszy



Program Officer Email Address: rfragasz@nsf.gov



Program Officer Phone Number: (703)292-8360



Unsaturated expansive
and collapsible soils are some of the most widely distributed and costly
geologic hazards in the U.S. Expansive soils alone cover one-fourth of the
U.S., and cause about $15 billion’s damage to infrastructure annually. Nearly
all landslides in the U.S. are related to unsaturated soils and result in 25–50
deaths/yr and more than $2 billion/yr in repair cost. Solving the above-mentioned
widespread geohazards requires a fundamental understanding of constitutive
behavior of unsaturated soils. In the past six decades, suction-controlled triaxial
test had been established as a standard approach to characterize constitutive
behavior for unsaturated soils. However, this types of tests require
sophisticated and costly testing equipment (usually $150,000/equipment), is
very laborious and time-consuming (2-3 years/soil) and cannot be justified for
routing engineering projects.



This NSF EAGER project
investigated the feasibility of using results from undrained triaxial tests to
model constitutive behavior for unsaturated soils. It is found that soil
specimens in the triaxial tests can be used as representative element volume to
characterize unsaturated soil behavior before failure. When the soil specimens
approach failure, strain localizations might occur. In addition, this project
also investigated the possibility of using conventional triaxial test apparatus
to characterize unsaturated soil constitutive behavior. A new photogrammetry-based
method was developed to measure the total and local volume changes for unsaturated
soils during triaxial testing with consideration of refraction. Real three
dimensional soil volume changes can be obtained by analyzing pictures from routine
commercial digital cameras. Preliminary validation tests indicated the results
had very high accuracy.



In as summary,
results obtained this NSF EAGER project indicated that it is possible to use
conventional low-cost triaxial test apparatus for saturated soils to
characterize constitutive behavior for unsaturated soils. The testing time can
be reduced by 1000 times (2-3 weeks/soil) if undrained tests are used. The
obtained results can be more accurate and theorectically correct. All these can
significantly reduce the time and cost associated with characterization of
unsaturated soil behavior. Ultimately, the benefits will be potentially saving
billions of dollars in solving the widespread unsaturated soil-related
problems. More research is however needed in this direction


Last Modified: 04/06/2013
Modified by: Xiong Zhang
